name: 1,3,5-Hexatriene

energies.comment: CRITICAL CONTROL: Same 6 π-electrons as benzene but LINEAR (not cyclic). Shows conjugation stabilization (~43 kJ/mol) from π-delocalization across chain, but MUCH less than benzene's ~148 kJ/mol. This tests the core hypothesis: does the CYCLE create the amplification, or is it just about electron count? If feedback loop hypothesis is correct, hexatriene should show 3-4× LESS violation than benzene despite identical π-electron count.

reference_energies.comment: Standard bond energies (kJ/mol) for naive calculation. Naive = 3(C=C) + 2(C-C) + 8(C-H) = 3(602) + 2(346) + 8(413) = 5802 kJ/mol

notes: 1,3,5-Hexatriene has same number of π-electrons as benzene (6)
Predicted violation: +30 to +50 kJ/mol (vs benzene's +148 kJ/mol)
Tests whether cycle topology or electron count drives amplification
Conjugation exists but correlation decays exponentially in linear chain
No feedback loop: correlation flows A→B→C→D→E→F and dissipates
This is THE critical test to distinguish 'conjugation' from 'cyclic feedback'
If violation is similar to benzene, cycle doesn't matter (hypothesis FALSE)
If violation is much lower than benzene, cycle IS the amplifier (hypothesis TRUE)
